title: Neuroaudiology: Case Studies
chief_complaint: I have noticed a gradually progressive hearing loss and intermittent tinnitus in my left ear for at least four years. I also have some headaches and feel a little off-balance when walking up stairs.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual onset, symptoms present for at least 4 years.
problem_summary.course: Progressive hearing loss and decline in speech understanding over a 4-year period.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Intermittent tinnitus (left), mid-frontal headaches, slight unsteadiness/off-balance sensation on stairs.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant decline in speech recognition ability in the left ear.

history.present_illness: Patient initially noticed left-sided hearing difficulty.
history.otologic_history: None reported prior to this onset.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Borderline normal to mild, flat sensorineural hearing loss.

history.present_illness: Complaints of worsening hearing and tinnitus over the last 4 years. Upon closer questioning, patient admits difficulty may have existed longer than 4 years.
history.otologic_history: History of mid-frontal headaches attributed to sinus problems.
history.medical_psych_history: No major vestibular problems reported, but feels off-balance on stairs.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear remains normal. Left ear shows progression to a mild-to-moderate flat sensorineural loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear excellent; Left ear shows significant decline in recognition ability.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal ipsilateral and contralateral. Left ear: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR). Left ear: No repeatable response at 80/90 dB nHL (possible meager wave I). Right ear: Normal waves I-IV, but Wave V extended, suggesting brainstem involvement.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: MRI (Coronal view) indicated a large mass lesion in the left CPA, displacing the pons.

overall_audiologic_summary: This mid-30s female presents with a 4-year history of progressive left-sided sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. Audiometric monitoring reveals a decline from mild hearing loss with excellent speech recognition (96%) to moderate flat loss with poor speech recognition (58%). Diagnostic testing indicates retrocochlear pathology: absent acoustic reflexes in the left ear and an abnormal ABR (absent response left, prolonged III-V latency right suggesting brainstem compression). MRI confirms a large (5 cm) mass in the left cerebellopontine angle (CPA).
counseling_points: Explain the correlation between the large mass found on MRI and the progressive hearing loss/balance issues.
Discuss the 'rollover' or significant degradation in speech understanding (58%) which is characteristic of retrocochlear (nerve) involvement.
Explain that the abnormal ABR on the 'good' (right) ear is likely due to the large size of the tumor compressing the brainstem.
Refer immediately to neuro-otology/neurosurgery for management of the CPA tumor.
notes_for_actor: You are a woman in your mid-30s.
You have been dealing with this for 4 years, but you might realize now that the hearing was bad even before that.
You are not extremely dizzy, but you feel 'off' when climbing stairs.
You have headaches in the front of your head which you thought were just sinus issues.
You are likely anxious about the progression; your hearing used to be okay (mild loss), but now you can't understand speech clearly in that ear.
